 In case you want to disable using builders then you can use the `NoOpBuilderProvider` by creating a `org.mapstruct.ap.spi.BuilderProvider` file in the `META-INF/services` directory with `org.mapstruct.ap.spi.NoOpBuilderProvider` as it's content.

+[[mapping-with-constructors]]

+

replies.bodyText: I think we should have an opt-out for this functionality.. Lets do this from the start :).
replies.author: sjaakd

timeline.author: sjaakd
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -528,3 +528,72 @@ Otherwise, you would need to write a custom `BuilderProvider`
 ====
 In case you want to disable using builders then you can use the `NoOpBuilderProvider` by creating a `org.mapstruct.ap.spi.BuilderProvider` file in the `META-INF/services` directory with `org.mapstruct.ap.spi.NoOpBuilderProvider` as it's content.
 ====
+
+[[mapping-with-constructors]]
+=== Using Constructors
+
+MapStruct also support using constructors for mapping target types.
+When doing a mapping MapStruct checks if there is a builder for the type being mapped.
+If there is no builder, then MapStruct looks for a single accessible constructor.
+WHen there are multiple constructors then the following is done to pick one that should be used:
+
+* If a parameterless constructor exists then it would be used to construct the object and the others would be ignored
+* If there are multiple constructors then the one annotated with annotation named `@Default` (from any package) would be used
+
+
+When using a constructor then the names of the parameters of the constructor would be used as the target properties.
+If the constructor is annoated with an annotation named `@ConstructorProperties` (from any package) then this would be used to get the names of the parameters.

replies.bodyText: Many time the user does not have control over the objects. Take for instance lombok, but also XJC generated classes. How would we handle those? What about name based mapping?
replies.author: sjaakd

replies.bodyText: How would a name based mapping look like? There is no name for the constructor, they are all the same 😄. However, if there is a public empty constructor then it would use that one
replies.author: filiphr

replies.bodyText:
Wel. I was thinking: you made an annotation @ConstructorProperties? Perhaps we could have a (optional) property in @BeanMapping#targetConstructorProperties. When present it acts as a substitute for the one on the target.
Thinking more about it.. What happens we apply @ConstructorProperties to more than one constructor? Should we allow such case: then how should we handle it? Or should we return an error?

filiphr

replies.bodyText: I realise that (now). But what about the idea of using the targetConstructorProperties?

timeline.message:
#73 Add support for using constructor arguments when instantiating mapping targets

By default the constructor argument names are used to extract the target properties.
If a constructor is annotated with an annotation named `@ConstructorProperties` (from any package) then it would be used to extract the target properties.

If a mapping target has a parameterless empty constructor it would be used to instantiate the target.
When there are multiple constructors then an annotation named `@Default` (from any package) can be used to mark a constructor that should be used by default when instantiating the target.

Supports mapping into Java 14 Records and Kotlin data classes out of the box

#73 Add support for using constructor arguments when instantiating mapping targets

By default the constructor argument names are used to extract the target properties.
If a constructor is annotated with an annotation named `@ConstructorProperties` (from any package) then it would be used to extract the target properties.

If a mapping target has a parameterless empty constructor it would be used to instantiate the target.
When there are multiple constructors then an annotation named `@Default` (from any package) can be used to mark a constructor that should be used by default when instantiating the target.

Supports mapping into Java 14 Records and Kotlin data classes out of the box
